oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Willard Walton with wooden sculpture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carver Willard Walton in glasses and a blue plaid shirt, in profile. He is holding a sassafras root. Walton, a folk artist, performer, and sassafras seller, uses his woodworking and whittling skills to create animals from tree stumps and tree roots

Walton's contribution highlights a multi-medium folk artist inspired by his family history, his natural surroundings, his life experiences, and his military service in India. His woodcraft gained national prominence, and advertisements for his walking and his military service in India. His woodcraft gained national prominence, and advertisements for his walking sticks appeared in New York Magazine as early as the 1970s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wood-carvers--United States; Country life--United States; Folk art -- United States
Wood Carvings; Carving; Sculpture
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lawless, Elaine
